questions.question: Which of the following best describes the core principle of the McNaughten Rule in determining legal insanity?

options.A: The accused was suffering from a delusion at the time of the offence.
options.B: The accused could not control their actions due to a mental disorder.
options.C: The accused could not understand the nature or wrongness of their actions due to a mental defect.
options.D: The accused had a history of psychiatric illness before the offence.

questions.explanation: to a mental defect. Correct Answer: C) The accused could not understand the nature or wrongness of their actions due to a mental defect. Explanation: the McNaughten Rule , which is the legal test for insanity recognised in Section 22 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS), 2023 , derived from Section 84 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) . Section 22, BNS states: "Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law." The principle focuses on cognitive incapacity — not knowing the nature or wrongfulness of the act. Lucid Interval: Definition : A period during insanity when symptoms completely disappear. Judgment : Individual can soundly judge their actions and are legally liable. Variability : Duration varies between individuals and over time for the same individual. Legal Implications : Difficulty in determining mental state at the time of an offence complicates full responsibility. Common in : Conditions like mania and melancholia. During a lucid interval, an individual is capable of sound judgment and understanding their actions, making them legally responsible for their conduct. If a crime is committed during this period, according to the McNaghten Rule , the individual could be held accountable for their actions. Sec. 84 IPC deals with the criminal responsibility of insane persons. It states that: “Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, because of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or what he is doing is either wrong or contrary to the law”. BNS Section 22: Nothing is an offence done by a person who, at the time of doing it, because of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law. McNaughten Rule: The key principle states that every person is presumed sane until proven otherwise. To establish a defence of insanity, it must be proven that the accused, at the time of the act, had a mental disease that prevented them from understanding the nature of the act or recognising it as wrong. Legal Test of Insanity (Right or Wrong Test): A person is not criminally responsible if they did not know the nature of their act or that it was wrong at the time of the crime. questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a rule for criminally insane individuals?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Morrison's Rule Explanation: Morrison’s Rule is not a recognised rule related to the criminal responsibility of insane individuals. Morrison's Rule states that after five months of fetal development, the crown-heel length in centimetres can be divided by five to estimate the fetal age in months. This provides a simple method for assessing gestational age based on fetal size. Criminal responsibility of insane persons rules: Durham’s Rule (1954) : An accused is not criminally responsible if their unlawful act results from a mental disease or defect. (Option B ruled out) Curren’s Rule (1964) : An accused is not criminally responsible if, due to a mental disease or defect, they were unable to regulate their conduct according to the law at the time of the act. (Option A ruled out) American Law Institute Test (1970) : A person is not responsible for criminal actions if, due to mental disease or defect, they lack adequate capacity to understand the wrongfulness of their actions or to conform to legal requirements. (Option C ruled out) Brawner Rule (1972) : Insanity determinations should be made by a jury, which has the discretion to decide the "insanity question." The Irresistible Impulse : This rule posits that an individual may recognize an act as illegal but, due to mental impairment, cannot control their actions. For example, Lorena Bobbitt was acquitted in 1994 by arguing that an irresistible impulse led her to commit her crime. Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 417 https://www.intech open.com/chapters/78121#:~:text=Morrison%20rule%2C%20after%20five%20months%20of%20fetal%20life%2C %20the%20crown%20heel%20length%20in%20cm%20is%20divided%20by%20the%20number%20five%20to%20 reach%20the%20fetal%20age%20in%20months

questions.question: Identify the FALSE statement on civil responsibilities of the insane from the following options: ceremony.

options.A: A contract is void if one party lacks mental capacity at the time of the agreement.
options.B: Mentally ill individuals can serve as guardians for their own property.
options.C: The Hindu Marriage Act permits annulment if one party is mentally unfit at the time of the
options.D: A holographic will must be entirely in the testator's handwriting and meet specific validity criteria.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Mentally ill individuals can serve as guardians for their own property. managers under the Mental Healthcare Act, 2017 or Guardians and Wards Act, 1890 , when a person is mentally incapable of managing their property. Mentally ill individuals cannot be entrusted with the management of their own or others’ estates. This also aligns with Section 22 of BNS, 2023 , which replaces IPC Section 84 and states that a person incapable of understanding the nature of their act due to mental illness is not criminally liable , further indicating lack of civil capacity. Forensic-Legal Notes: Section 22, BNS 2023 (Replaces IPC Sec 84): Protects mentally ill individuals from criminal liability if incapable of understanding their actions. Section 89, IPC/BNS: Consent by children under 12 or by persons of unsound mind is invalid; only the guardian’s consent is valid for acts done in good faith for their benefit. Section 90, IPC/BNS: Consent is invalid if given by someone incapable of understanding the nature and consequences of the act due to unsoundness of mind or intoxication, or if given under fear or misconception of fact. Section 118, Indian Evidence Act : Mentally ill individuals can testify only if capable of understanding questions and giving rational answers . Civil Law presumes mental competence unless legally proven otherwise . A contract is void if one party lacks mental capacity at the time of the agreement (Option A): Indian Contract Act, 1872 (Section 11) states that a person must be of sound mind to enter into a valid contract. If proven that a party lacked mental capacity at the time, the contract is void ab initio , unless made during a lucid interval . Such an individual is deemed legally incapable of understanding or forming rational judgments required for binding agreements. The Hindu Marriage Act permits annulment if one party is mentally unfit at the time of the ceremony (Option C): Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 – Section 5(ii) : Declares a marriage invalid if either party was incapable of giving valid consent due to unsoundness of mind. Annulment is permissible if one party is mentally unfit for marriage or procreation. Under Muslim law , a woman may seek divorce if the husband suffers from insanity for over 2 years . A holographic will must be entirely in the testator's handwriting and meet specific validity criteria (Option D): Though not specifically defined under Indian law, a holographic will is recognised as valid if: It is entirely handwritten and signed by the testator. Meets the criteria under Section 63 of the Indian Succession Act, 1925 . The testator must be of sound mind at the time of making the will (Testamentary Capacity). Individuals who are intoxicated , delusional , or suffering from advanced mental illness at the time cannot make valid wills.

questions.question: Which of the following best differentiates hallucination from illusion in perception disorders? of a real external stimulus.

options.A: Hallucination occurs with external stimuli, while illusion occurs without any stimuli.
options.B: Hallucination is a false perception without an external stimulus, while illusion is a misinterpretation
options.C: Hallucination and illusion are both voluntary perceptions of external objects.
options.D: Hallucination is always visual, while illusion is always auditory.

questions.explanation: a misinterpretation of a real external stimulus. Correct Answer: B) Hallucination is a false perception without an external stimulus, while illusion is a misinterpretation of a real external stimulus. Explanation: Hallucinations involve perceptions without any actual external stimuli, while illusions are distortions or misinterpretations of real stimuli. For example, seeing objects that do not exist (hallucination) versus mistaking a rope for a snake (illusion). Hallucination: Hallucination is a false perception experienced by the senses without any external stimulus. It can occur in conditions like insanity, high fever, drug intoxication, and withdrawal. (Option A ruled out) Types of Hallucinations: (Option D ruled out) Visual : Seeing non-existent sights, common in disorders like schizophrenia and conversion disorder. Auditory (most common type) : Hearing sounds or voices without a source, prevalent in schizophrenia. Olfactory : False perception of smells, often associated with schizophrenia and temporal lobe epilepsy. Gustatory : Experiencing tastes without food, noted in certain medical conditions. Tactile : Feeling sensations like crawling insects on the skin, seen in cocaine use and schizophrenia. Psychomotor : Feeling movement in body parts without actual movement. Lilliputian : Perception of objects being smaller than they are, more like an illusion. Auditory hallucinations are the most common , followed by visual ones. Hallucinations are involuntary and can lead to dangerous behaviours. Some auditory hallucinations occurring while falling asleep ( hypnagogic ) or waking up ( hypnopompic ) are considered normal experiences. Illusion: Illusion is a false interpretation of an external object or stimulus that has real existence. (Option A ruled out) It can be classified as: Universal Illusions: Common to all individuals and unchanging, such as the appearance of converging railway tracks. Personal Illusions: Vary between individuals, such as misidentifying a doctor as a family member or mistaking a dog for a lion. A sane person can correct these false impressions, while an insane person persists in believing them despite clear evidence. Illusions are often associated with psychoses, particularly of the organic type. Hallucination and illusion are both voluntary perceptions of external objects. (Option C): Both hallucinations and illusions are involuntary; individuals cannot control these experiences, especially hallucinations. Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine, KS Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page 369 Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 404, 405

questions.question: Match the following types of delusions with their appropriate descriptions. 1. Othello Syndrome a) Belief that one is dead or putrefying. 2. Cotard Syndrome b) Belief that a spouse is unfaithful. 3. de Clérambault’s Syndrome c) Belief of being infested with parasites. 4. Ekbom Syndrome d) Belief that a higher-status person loves the individual.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c Explanation: Delusion: Delusion is a firmly held false belief based on incorrect inferences about external reality, despite evidence to the contrary. It is a symptom of schizophrenia and is not typically seen in neurotic disorders. Medico-legal Importance: Diminished responsibility can apply to individuals committing unlawful acts due to delusions. Types of Delusions: Delusion of Grandeur : Belief of being very important or wealthy, often seen in mania. Delusion of Poverty : Conviction of impending loss of all material possessions. Delusion of Infidelity/Jealousy (Othello Syndrome) : Belief that a spouse is unfaithful, leading to extreme actions. Males are more commonly affected. Delusion of Reference : Belief that media and others refer to the individual, often negatively. Delusion of Persecution : Belief that one is being harmed or poisoned by others, leading to potential violence. Delusion of Influence/Control : Belief that one's thoughts and actions are controlled by external forces. Hypochondriacal Delusion : Persistent fear of having a serious illness based on unrealistic interpretations. Delusion of Self-Reproach/Criticism : Self-blame for imagined offences, potentially leading to suicide. Nihilistic Delusion : Belief that one does not exist or that the world does not exist, often seen in depression. Delusion of Doubles (Doppelganger) : Patients believe that another person has been physically transformed into themselves. Erotomania (de Clérambault’s Syndrome) : Belief that someone of higher social status is in love with the individual. Capgras Syndrome : Belief that a close person has been replaced by an exact double. Fregoli’s Phenomenon : Strangers are identified as familiar people. Ekbom Syndrome (Delusions of Parasitosis) : Belief of being infested with parasites. Folie à Deux : Shared delusions between two people. Cotard Delusion/Syndrome : Belief that one is dead, does not exist, is putrefying, or has lost blood or internal organs. Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine, KS Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page 368, 369 Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 403, 404

questions.question: A 45 y/o man is brought to the psychiatric clinic by his wife. He claims that his wife has been replaced by an impostor who looks exactly like her but is not his real wife. He reports feeling anxious and confused about why others cannot see the difference. His medical history includes a previous diagnosis of paranoid schizophrenia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Capgras syndrome Explanation: The patient believes that his wife has been replaced by an impostor, which is characteristic of Capgras syndrome. Delusion of Doubles (Doppelganger) : Patients believe that another person has been physically transformed into themselves. (Option A ruled out) Capgras Syndrome : A delusion where a patient believes a close person has been replaced by an exact double. Fregoli's Phenomenon : A delusion where strangers are misidentified as familiar people from the patient's life. (Option C ruled out) Associated Mental Illnesses : Delusions are typically seen in schizophrenia, but not in neurotic illnesses. Medico-Legal Relevance : Delusions can impact legal responsibility under the doctrine of diminished responsibility. A person may not be fully accountable for unlawful acts if the delusion impairs their reasoning. Schizoaffective disorder (Option D) : While this disorder involves psychotic symptoms, the specific delusion of impostor replacement points to Capgras syndrome. Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 404

questions.question: A 25 y/o woman presents to the dermatologist with intense itching and anxiety, convinced that tiny insects are crawling on her skin. She frequently inspects her body and applies various lotions to prevent what she believes are infestations, although no evidence of insects or bites is found on examination. She is aware that her fear may be exaggerated, but she cannot stop feeling anxious about it. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Acarophobia Explanation: Acarophobia is the fear of mites or small insects crawling on the skin, which fits the patient's symptoms of irrational anxiety about infestations without objective evidence. Phobias and Impulses: Phobias : Classified under Neurotic and Somatoform Disorders. Defined as a persistent, unrealistic, and intense fear of an object or situation, often recognised as irrational by the individual. Types of phobias: Agoraphobia : Fear of open spaces, crowds, or leaving home; commonly affects women and may involve panic attacks. (Option D) Social Phobia : Fear of social interactions or situations (e.g., public speaking). Specific Phobia : Fear of particular objects or situations, examples include: Acrophobia Fear of heights (Option C) Acarophobia Fear of mites/insects (Option B) Claustrophobia Fear of confined spaces Needle Phobia Fear of injections Algophobia Fear of pain Xenophobia Abnormal fear of strangers Gamophobia Fear of marriage/relationships Zoophobia Fear of animals Impulses : Highlighted in forensic psychiatry due to potential links to criminal behaviour. Defined as sudden, irresistible forces driving a person to act without motive or forethought. Types of impulses: Kleptomania Compulsive stealing Dipsomania Compulsive drinking of alcohol Pyromania Urge to set fires Mutilomania Desire to harm animals Oniomania Compulsive shopping Trichotillomania Compulsive hair-pulling Suicidal Impulse The urge to commit suicide, often triggered by intoxication Homicidal Impulse Urge to commit homicide, linked to chronic intoxication Delusional parasitosis (Option A) : In delusional parasitosis, patients have a fixed false belief of being infested with parasites, typically without insight into the irrationality of their belief. Causes of Delusional Parasitosis Primary Psychiatric Disorders: Schizophrenia Bipolar disorder Depression Anxiety OCD Illness anxiety disorder Medical Causes: Illnesses : Hyperthyroidism, B12/folate deficiencies, diabetes. Neurological : Dementia, stroke, multiple sclerosis. Substance Abuse : Methamphetamine, alcohol withdrawal, cocaine. Infections : HIV, tuberculosis, leprosy, syphilis. Medications : Topiramate, ciprofloxacin, steroids, ketoconazole.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the Mental Healthcare Act (MHCA) 2017 is NOT true? of Persons with Disabilities. 1987. advance.

options.A: The Act aims to align mental healthcare services with the United Nations Convention on the Rights
options.B: It allows for both voluntary and involuntary admissions, with specific protocols for each.
options.C: The MHCA 2017 came into effect on July 7, 2020, replacing the previous Mental Health Act of
options.D: It introduces advance directives that enable individuals to express their treatment preferences in

questions.explanation: Health Act of 1987. Correct Answer: C) The MHCA 2017 came into effect on July 7, 2020, replacing the previous Mental Health Act of 1987 Explanation: The MHCA 2017 came into effect on July 7, 2018 , not 2020. Mental Healthcare Act (MHCA) 2017 in India: Overview of the Act : Purpose : Aims to provide comprehensive mental healthcare and services, aligning with the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (2006). (Option A ruled out) Implementation Date : Enacted on July 7, 2018, replacing the Mental Health Act of 1987. Key Provisions : Rights Protection : Focuses on protecting and promoting the rights of individuals during mental healthcare delivery; ensures treatment in the least restrictive environment. Admission Procedures : Specifies detailed protocols for voluntary and involuntary admissions; all admissions require notification to a Mental Health Review Board (MHRB) for stays exceeding 30 days. (Option B ruled out) Advance Directives : Introduces advance directives and nominated representatives, allowing individuals to express treatment preferences in advance . (Option D ruled out) Implementation Challenges : Resource Limitations : Acknowledges limited mental healthcare resources in India; provides a 10-year timeline for meeting international standards in human resource development for mental healthcare. Transition from Previous Legislation : Introduces stringent involuntary admission procedures compared to MHA 1987, requiring legal formalities that may delay treatment. Conclusion : The MHCA 2017 is a progressive step towards improving mental health care in India. Success depends on effective implementation despite existing resource constraints. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8277537/

questions.question: A 34-year-old man is brought to the psychiatric unit after assaulting a bystander without provocation. He reports months of auditory hallucinations with threatening voices, disorganized thoughts, and paranoid delusions. He is distressed, has poor hygiene, has a flat affect, and shows no signs of manipulation or substance abuse. What is the most likely explanation for his symptoms?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) True insanity Explanation: Given the presence of long-standing auditory hallucinations, paranoid delusions, disorganized thoughts, flat affect (a severe reduction in emotional expressiveness.), and poor hygiene, these are classic features of a psychotic disorder and suggest a genuine mental illness rather than feigned symptoms. True vs. Feigned Insanity: Individuals may feign insanity to avoid criminal responsibility. Feature True Insanity (Option A) Feigned Insanity (Option B) Onset Gradual Sudden Motive Absent Present (e.g., after a crime) Predisposing Factors Usually present (e.g., family history) Absent Signs and Symptoms Uniform, specific Variable, exaggerated Activity Careless, persists even when unobserved Only present when observed Mood Excited, depressed, fluctuating Overacted to appear abnormal Facial Expression Peculiar, vacant, worried Frequently changing, exaggerated Insomnia Present Inconsistent, resolves in a day or two Exertion Can endure exertion, fatigue Breaks down after short exertion Habits Dirty and filthy Clean, not neglected Dressing Careless Reasonably proper Skin and Lips Dry, harsh Normal Tongue Coated Clean Repeated Examinations Doesn't mind Resists for fear of detection Delusional disorder (Option C) involves fixed, non-bizarre delusions without prominent hallucinations or disorganised thinking, whereas this patient has broader psychotic symptoms like hallucinations and thought disorganisation. Personality disorder (Option D) does not typically present with acute psychotic symptoms such as auditory hallucinations or severe disorganisation. Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 407, 408, 409

questions.question: A 25 y/o man is brought to the ED after being found wandering outside his home late at night, appearing confused and disoriented. He has no recollection of the events that occurred while he was outside. This behaviour is consistent with which of the following?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Somnambulism Explanation: Somnambulism , or sleepwalking, involves automatic motor activity during sleep with no recollection upon awakening, consistent with the patient’s behaviour. Criminal Responsibility in Specific Cases: Delirium: Type: Organic mental disorder. Definition: An acute reversible mental disorder characterised by confusion and impaired consciousness. Context: Occurs in individuals with high fever, overwork, mental stress, acute poisoning, or chronic alcohol/drug intoxication. (Option A) Criminal Responsibility : Individuals may not be responsible for criminal acts due to impaired consciousness and irrational behaviour. Run Amok : (Run Amok) Definition: Describes an individual engaging in frenzied violence without clear provocation. Cultural Context: Aligns with Section 84 of the IPC , stating that a person is not liable for acts committed under unsoundness of mind. Causes of run amok: Chronic poisoning of Cannabis sativa Somnambulism (Sleepwalking) : Category: Parasomnia involving automatic motor activity during sleep with no recollection upon waking. (Option B) Criminal Responsibility : Individuals committing criminal acts during sleepwalking episodes are not held responsible. Sleep disorders in different phases of the cycle: Sleep apnea It occurs in the deeper sleep phases, primarily affecting stage N3 and REM sleep. Narcolepsy It involves skipping initial sleep phases and directly entering REM sleep, leading to persistent daytime sleepiness. This results in reduced N3 deep sleep and irregular sleep patterns. REM sleep disorder It involves acting out dreams with vocalizations and movements due to disrupted muscle atonia during REM sleep. Somnambulism or sleepwalking It occurs during non-REM sleep, typically in the N3 phase. This is when individuals can make purposeful movements without acting out their dreams, which happens in REM sleep. Sleep Drunkenness : Definition: A form of hypersomnia where individuals experience confusion and disorientation during the transition from sleep to wakefulness. Criminal Responsibility : Individuals are not responsible for violent acts performed while in this state. Kleptomania : Type : Impulse disorder characterised by a compulsion to steal items of little value. Criminal Responsibility : Courts may consider kleptomania as a mental disorder affecting impulse control (not guilty under the New Hampshire Doctrine), which could influence sentencing or lead to treatment rather than punishment. (MHCA 2017) Hypnosis : (Option D) Context: Not explicitly addressed but related to "delusion of influence/control". questions.question: Which of the following statements is true about Psychosis?

options.A: In psychosis, contact with reality is often preserved.
options.B: Individuals with psychosis typically exhibit empathy
options.D: An organic causative factor is present.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) An organic causative factor is present. Explanation: Psychosis vs Neurosis Features Psychosis Neurosis 1. Contact with reality Lost Preserved (Option A ruled out) 2. Interpersonal behavior Marked disturbance in personality and behaviour Preserved 3. Empathy Absent Present (Option B ruled out) 4. Insight Absence of understanding of current symptoms (insight absent) Symptoms are recognized as undesirable (insight present) (Option C ruled out) 5. Organic causative factor Present Absent 6. Symptoms Delusions, illusions and hallucinations Usually physical or psychic symptoms 7. Dealing with reality Capacity is grossly impaired Preserved 8. Examples Dementia, schizophrenia Anxiety, phobia, depression, conversion disorder. Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 406
